ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .

The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Perfect survey course of river processes.

Jim and Jenn are an awesome team. The only reason my comments on the field trips were a bit more neutral was that I could not attend all of them.Jim is one of those lecturers whose practical experience in the field makes him so on-point, and totally in command of the material. He is so much fun to take classes with I really respect him. He collaborates with students and makes an effort to explain complicated concepts clearly and provide opportunities to reinforce learning with field experience. THe last couple of classes he made new slides to respond to specific subjects of student interest. Just great. This could be a really straightforward course and he chooses to elevate it. Thanks, Jim!

We grappled with a lot of material in the course, and the instructor presented a breadth of material in a very clear and approachable manner. The professor and the TF have a great enthusiasm for the subject and it shows.

Jim MacBroom's energy, enthusiasm, and thoughtfulness are on display every day. I cannot even guess how many days he must have spent outside of class, taking students on field trips, visiting project sites. He must be the hardest working, most committed professor at FES. He spent almost 4 hours with me, one-on-one at my field site. We had a great time and I learned a lot.
Jim's teaching is awesome! He made the class feel small and welcoming. I enjoyed all aspects of the course. Jenn is also amazing and was so helpful with questions!
Limit class size
The class is very practical and applied.

1. The readings for the class are especially useful as reference materials, but they are not the kinds of readings that warrant reading straight through (the 450-page Army Corps of Engineers Channel Restoration Design Manual, for instance).9. The field trips were very successful in demonstrating concepts from the class. The instructorâs extensive knowledge about (and enthusiasm for) Connecticutâs streams made them all the more worthwhile.10. The instructor was good at explaining the material, but it would have been helpful to have more problem sets along the way; it also would have been helpful to have a class in the computer lab, where we could work together to learn how to use some of the software thatâs currently utilized in river planning and restoration (USGS StreamStats, HEC-RAS, etc.).14. I think the class is valuable to students with similar interests as mine. Even though Iâm an MF candidate, I think this class was extremely valuable. Water quality is an important goal of a lot of forest management, and itâs great to better understand the determinants of water quality, in addition to the factors affecting the physical and biological nature of streams.
This course was interesting, well-organized, and relevant to many other courses offered at FES. Jim and Jenn's commitment to the students was impressive, and much appreciated. Overall, excellent!

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The field trips are certainly the best part. Thank you for a wonderful semester, Jenn and Jim! You guys are an awesome duo.

Field trips were very helpful at bringing concepts to life and making connections from in-class discussionsJenn Hoyle is very good at explaining the materialAssignments help you to deepen your understanding of the materialProfessor MacBroom clearly loves teaching students about his field
Covered both hydrology and more advanced restoration.

The field trips were invaluable for learning! The assignments corresponded appropriately with the field trips, and were graded fairly.The group project was useful. At first I was not pleased that it was real-world vs. literature research, but I learned a lot from the data collection& analysis!
Great prof., TF, and course.
See above
The combination of lectures, field trips, projects and problem sets, which allowed us to tackle both analytical and conceptual problems and apply our new skills to real world client-based projects.
Jim's enthusiasm and his experience as a practitioner.
I really appreciated the field trips. They were well designed, illustrated the topics we covered in class, and they were fun!Jim's powerpoint slides are also quite good.

Jim's responsiveness to questions and sharing his depth of experience. Also, the story about Jim attaching himself to a railing during a hurricane just so he could monitor tide gates on his own time was incredible. A story I will never forget. :)
It is applied.

Professor MacBroom's enthusiasm for river restoration is contagious and his knowledge on the topic is extensive. The field trips were a great way to apply and visualize what we were learning in class.

The fact that Jim has been working in this field for many years makes for a much more interesting lecture. His ability to add personal experience and stories to the subject matter make for a dynamic and compelling class.
Jim's expertise and most of the restoration projects he talked about he actually worked on.
The group project and field trips provide great hands-on learning opportunities and glimpses into real-world problem solving.
The field trips were extremely helpful in solidifying the information we read about and learned in class. Jim was an excellent instructor, especially in the field.
Field trips! They were really helpful to learn and apply what was discussed in the classroom.

One of the best aspects of the course is that the instructor is an experienced practitioner who has planned and designed a great variety of stream restoration projects. This course strikes a good balance between the qualitative and quantitative aspects of river assessments and analysis. It is also useful to learn how streams are classified and to become familiar with the two prominent river classification systems. Lastly,the instructor is hilarious and incredibly engaging!
I liked the field trips a lot. It was a great way to visualize what we had learned in class. The instructor was great and a lot of fun.
Many useful topics that introduce students into the world of river restoration.
Field trips were great and made the information presented in lectures clear and relevant.
The field trips were very interesting and supplemented the lectures perfectly. The instructor is enthusiastic, which makes the course enjoyable.
Great course with lots of real world applicability. Was great interacting with and learning from Jim and Jenn.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I think that this course would benefit with a smaller class size. There were too many students for appropriate access with Jim. That said, Jenn worked tirelessly to make the semester work as well as it did with the numbers.Also, I think that incorporating in-class discussions or in-class problem solving/problem sets would be beneficial to drive home important concepts. 3 hour lectures are tough for anybody to sit through!

The power point slides are difficult to follow sometimes, and the updated slides are not always posted on Classes v2The channelization paper assignment was kind of vague - I wasn't sure how much general channelization information to include rather than just addressing the river channelization from the field trip
I think a larger section on land use impacts on river process would be very good- we essentially just look at the river itself, not the surrounding hydrology.

I think the final project was a bit unclearMaybe we could do a couple more case studies - like they could give us a stream - hydrological data - dimensions - history - and we could provide recommendations

I appreciated the flexibility of the lecture structure during the last third of the semester, but also think that the format could be improved, possibly by providing additional readings or arranging more formal class discussions.
Three hours is a long time to pay attention!
I would like to see more lectures like the last few of the course, where specific issues or regions are discussed in detail.
I actually would have liked a little bit more math.
Stagger the work load more evenly through the semester.
Back half of the course needs more structure/content/accountability. The course really lost steam by the end.
I don't really have much to add here.

The midterm exam material seemed to be disconnected from the way the course was taught and material that was covered. It would be great to have Jim's textbook earlier on in the course (earlier than the day before the exam) since several of the exam questions seemed to come from this text.
I thought that the course worked well as is. It was a bit difficult having a 3 hour 20 minute long course, but it worked fine.

The weakest part of this class, I think, is the exams (and I'm not usually one to complain about exams). Thank goodness there were previous yearsâ exams to look over, because most of the questions were either (1) very ambiguous or (2) often unrelated to the material we covered. Otherwise, I thought the class itself was excellent!
Some of the material was presented in a confusing way. Also, the course had no text book so there wasn't a way to reference materials to reinforce what we were learning in class.
I feel some topics can go a bit deeper.
The exams weren't challenging so actually absorbing the material was difficult.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Good fit- they contributed well to the class.
Very effective. I really appreciated the effort to keep field trip groups small.
The relationship between the field trips and the class and projects was great.
We did not have a discussion/ lab section.
No discussion or lab section in this class.
Very closely related; field trips were excellent.
It was very effective.
Great overlap between lab and classroom discussions

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: She is superhuman to deal with the volume of grading, project coordination, and general questions. Thanks so much for a great semester, Jenn!
Jenn is super helpful and knowledgeable. When combined with Jim, power teaching team.
Jenn was absolutely great.
Jenn was an effective, competent, and helpful Teaching Assistant.

Jenn did a great job clarifying questions, reviewing material for the exam, organizing (and leading at least my classification field trip). She comes off as very knowledgeable and helpful, especially given such a large class size.
Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  Jenn really knows the material and has a lot of practical experience. She is very accessible by email and welcomes your questions.
Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  Very accesible. Overloaded on the group projects- the class either needs more TAs or fewer students to deal with the projects.

Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  Jenn was amazing and dedicated incredible amounts of her own time to this course! She made it succeed! It would not have worked without her knowledge and presence! She deserves to be considered at the highest TA level possible and get recognized for her dedication!
Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  Really super. Announcements about deadlines could benefit with slightly more communication.
Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  Jenn was AMAZING. I have no complaints whatsoever.
Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  She is very knowledgeable and good at answering questionsI learned SO MUCH in her review session - it would be great to have another couple of those

Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  The TF demonstrated expert knowledge, and showed enthusiasm and dedication to the course and the students. My only recommendation would be to allow for additional TF's in the event that the class size is comparable to this years.
Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  She was excellent!
Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  Jenn was always available and very responsive. The class was very large, so I can only recommend that a second TA might have made her life easier.
Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  She has a close relationship with Professor MacBroom and served as an excellent liaison between students and the professor.
Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  Jenn is an awesome TA. She is knowledgeable, available, quick to respond to questions, organized, and very helpful in making the class move smoothly.
Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  She worked with Jim previously so she understood what he expected and was able to explain certain topics in further detail.

Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  Jen was very knowledgable and had a lot of personal experience to draw upon to help teach us. She was extremely responsive to emails and questions in class.

Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  I canât say enough good things about Jenn, the TA. She is extremely knowledgeable, was always able to answer questions clearly, was very prompt in responding to questions over email, did an incredible job organizing all of the logistics for field trips, and is an incredibly kind and thoughtful person! She offered great feedback on assignments, organized a review session before the midterm, and was overall incredibly available to students. Jenn and the instructor also have a great rapport, and itâs a delight (and a privilege) to learn from them!
Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  Jennifer Hoyle was a great teaching assistant. She was approachable, knowledgeable and willing to help students understand the material.
Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  Very impressive with her knowledge and organization work.
Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  Jenn was incredibly knowledgeable and familiar with working with Jim. She was quick to reply with thoughtful, very helpful answers. Excellent job!
Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  Jenn was accessible and explained concepts very clearly.
Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  Jenn was great and well prepared.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Perfectly.

Rivers are applicable to anyone interested in the natural environment. It may not seem like it at first, but it really is! Jim discussed all types and locations of rivers so everyone can find a reason to need to understand rivers!
Forests and water go together like peas and carrots

I'm very interested in water resource issues in a variety of contexts. This course equipped me with the language tocommunicate with hydrologists, engineers, designers, and stakeholders working on river and river restoration issues.
I am interested in restoration, so it's very relevant.
It adds a bit of physical science to the mix of policy and water classes on which I am focusing.
Provides practical, useful, applied knowledge.
I am considering a career in restoration, so this class is very relevant to me.
I am considering a career in ecological restoration, so this course was very important, especially considering the paucity of restoration courses offered with the master's program.

This course does not directly relate to my research project or other courses I will be taking in these 2 years, but I think it will help me with future work after I graduate because I now better understand the role of a water way in a landscape.
This class fulfills one of the physical science requirements for the MF degree.
I am studying water resources management, so this course definitely fits in to my overall plan of study.
My interests in water/river management.

I am very interested in water, and this course contributes directly to field skills that apply to environmental management. While other courses felt more "academic" in nature, this was incredibly practical and helped me to feel more confident pursuing work in this field.
The coursework was extremely relevant and the field trips/final project provided me with practical field experience.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wished to learn about streams, stream restoration, and current/passed research on stream restoration. I believe my future work will be related to freshwater ecosystems and an understanding of streams will certainly be beneficial for me.
I took this course because I am interested in the restoration and conservation of rivers in the Middle East.
Interested in water and forests- so it seemed like a natural fit.
I needed another physical science credit and this was going to be better than anything with chemistry or the atmosphere... in my opinion
Water is important to us!
Required, interesting, challenging
I'm interested in water resources and watershed-scale management
Jim sounded great, the ability to do a course project was interesting, and I wanted to take another course inphysical science.
I have work experience in stream restoration so I wanted to learn the theory behind it.
Interest in watersheds and river management. Had most of my previous experience in urban rivers and wanted to expand on my professional experience.
I am considering a career in river restoration.
Learn more about rivers.
I want to be involved in stream and coastal ecosystem restoration projects and Jim has a wealth of experience to share with his students.
I took this class because I did not know very much about rivers and I felt they would be an important part of any landscape that I worked in.

I wouldnât consider myself someone who is naturally drawn to river systems, but I took this class because I wanted to better understand the link between land use and riverform/function. I had worked with local government in the environmental protection department previously, and, while I focused on sustainable forestry, our department as a whole did a lot of stream restoration work. Observing this process, I grew interested in learning how to classify and restore streams according to the Rosgen protocol, and this seemed like a great opportunity to get experience.
I took this course because I am studying water resources management, and I had never had the opportunity to learn about river restoration.
Intersts.
It had good reviews and seemed relevant to my interest.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: I felt like I was going to have a greater technical knowledge of restoration and was surprised to learn that the course had been stripped of most its math component. I was under the impression more hydrology would be present. That said, I think the course had the available resources presented to read much of the technical side of matters.

Yes. I think this course provides an overview of the processes and technology used in river restoration. I think it would be impossible to teach more than that in one semester. Professor MacBroom does a good job at providing an overview of his field, what it does, and how in the time permitted.
Yes.
Yes! It exceeded!
Yes.
Yes.
YesIt would be cool to do a couple more case studies on restoration projects to understand what can go well/ wrong more
Met or exceeded, I would say.
Yes

Yes, the course was just scientific enough that it satisfied my desire for depth but it did not get bogged down in equations and tables.The course scratches the surface of many aspects of rivers and management and Jim is so knowledgeable that he can direct you to deeper knowledge source (or give you a lecture on it himself)
Yes!
Yes
No, I had expected to be more competent and confident in my ability to make river assessments and that I would have acquired a higher level of technical skills.
Yes. Again, the course is practical and applied and I feel like I left with useful skills in watershed management plan development and river classification and assessment.
Yes.
Yes.
It would be great to see more of the computer modeling in the course, otherwise it seemed to be a good overview of stream restoration, classification, and processes.

Yes. I did not know what to expect when I started the class but after taking it I feel like I have a good understanding of how a river changes over time, how it impacts a landscape, and how to improve a waterway with management.
Yes, the knowledge and skills I gained in this class met and exceeded my expectations.
I learned a lot from this course. It definitely met my expectations.
I am hoping to learn more in the future.
Yes, and far surpassed my expectations.
Yes.
Course exceeded my expectations.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: The major benefit of group work is the opportunity for learning from classmates. I enjoyed working as a team despite the frustrations of seemingly slower progress on assignments. While I had several classmates in my group, I was able to take the most away from the student who had previous experience in the field and for that I was grateful.

I understand that group work is essential in this field, but it seemed difficult to do group work in this course because of hectic schedules, differing levels of experience, and different levels of engagement with the field site. We are currently trying to put our group presentation together and it is difficult to reach team members to develop a cohesive product. Some students have been working on their forest management projects at the site and seemed to transpose their field work from that project onto this project.
Advantage was that we could delve into our interests. Disadvantage was the difficulty of defining what our project was and how to do it.

Advantages were not doing data collection and analysis independently.Disadvantages were nothing unusual--compromising ideas, and scheduling/getting everyone to work at the same time.It was a good project!
Scheduling. Otherwise great to do teamwork.
Usual group work dynamics. Fine.
Advantages: you learn from expertise of others, get outsideDisadvantages: coordination and typical tragedy of the commons challenges

Advantages: balancing skill sets and collaborating with peers in a way that is more reflective of how river restoration projects are carried out in the fieldDisadvantages: having to compensate for other students who don't put forth equivalent effort.
Discussions were useful to fill gaps/ clarify topics from class and field trips.

Allowed me to meet new people and learn how others from different backgrounds approach problems and apply their skills/knowledge toward the project. Scheduling is always a challenge as everyone has various demands on their time.
Sharing work and observations. For this project, it was very helpful to have other people to work with and compare notes on observations.

It was extremely challenging to get one of our group members to contribute, despite giving numerous opportunities and "assignments" (although they did finally mention that they were facing health problems). I think we suffered from having too many people in our group and a little case of free-riding. I know its tough to have a huge number of groups given the size of the class, but perhaps limiting the size of groups to 3 could reduce some of the problems we had.In Coastal Governance, Prof. Burroughs had us rate team members in terms of participation, timeliness, etc. with a (Qualitrics?) survey before and after our group project. The survey beforehand was a good reminder of how to be good group workers, and results from the survey as part of our grade gave us extra incentive to perform well.

For our final project we were put into groups to write a report on a watershed or river of our choice. This was a great project because we had to apply all of the knowledge from class to writing a potentially useful management plan.

Group work was really useful during the site assessment part of our final project, in particular because the workload was too much for one person. Organizing a big group was somehow difficult and some team members worked more than others.
N/A

I found the group work to be one of the best parts of the course. I liked how applicable our projects were to the course work. We got to practice the field methods that we had learned about in class. I learned a lot from working with the group.
n/a

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Select a project that really interests you but has clear goals that you can accomplish within the scope of the class.
Take it!
Absolutely!
The readings are fascinating. Read what they give you and go seek out more on your own that pertain to issues or regions that you might be interested in studying.
Take it!
Take it! You don't want to miss this course with Jim MacBroom. And the student project is a great way to get practical experience on your resume.
Do it. Spend as much time with Jim and Jenn as possible.
If you have any interest in rivers, take this class.
Take it.
Jim has a wealth of knowledge and when he talks about a subject he really likes he can get very excited. Great class!

I would definitely suggest this course to anyone who is interested in working outdoors. Waterways are an important part of any landscape and Jim puts a lot of effort into making the class applicable to students' interests and backgrounds.

I strongly advise you to take this class, purchase the Rosgen field guide, and go on all of the field trips. For someone looking for a class that is conceptual but also very practical and applied, this is a great option. The instructor is terrific and the final project is very useful. There is also plenty of flexibility to take the concepts learned in the class and apply them in a way that is relevant to your particular interests.
a lot of learning depends on the student - how much deeper to go into each topic. interact with jim - he is awesome!
Take this course!
Take the course. You'll be glad you did.
Great class. Jim is extremely knowledgeable, dedicated and well respected in the field. This course was a major factor in my decision to enroll in FES.
